"Because of inactive lifestyles and stressful lives, many people are receiving lifestyle diseases such as diabetes, hypertension, etc. Fit India Movement can encourage people to consume healthy food and maintain physical and mental fitness."

"With high quality advertising and marketing practices, junk food manufacturers are manipulating children to buy their food. This Fit India movement will make children think of the negative consequences of junk food. As a result, this movement will encourage children to consume healthy foods."

"Some parents have put too much stress on children to study. They send their children to school after school or simply sit them down to do their homework forgetting the importance of free time to play. This movement has the potential to change its mind and, as a result, they can encourage their children to go out and play."

"This movement has the potential to make more people embrace traditional Indian martial art forms such as Kathi Samu, Musti Yudha, etc., and forms of traditional dance and even healthy Indian snacks. And as a by-product, this can lead to the creation of some jobs."
"The motivation to maintain fitness should begin from childhood. But in India, many schools lack playgrounds. The lack of playgrounds can push children to turn to inactive lifestyles."

"The India Fit movement cannot reach people below the poverty line. To maintain a healthy lifestyle, both physical activity and nutritious food are needed. But in India, still many people are malnourished and some people do not have access to safe drinking water. Therefore, without solving the question of poverty and the lack of access to nutritious food at affordable prices, a part of people in India will not be able to take advantage of this movement."

"Some people are already focusing on fitness. We can observe this with the increasing number of fitness startups. But this is a small percentage of people. In general, many people want to keep an active lifestyle, but all they need is some encouragement. So, this movement constantly reminds people to focus on fitness goals just like Swachh Bharat reminds us of the importance of keeping our environment clean."

"Since the invention of machines, the value of workers is decreasing. They're made to work to support the machines. As a result, work revolves around machines and not humans. Workers are forced to work continuously together with the machine."
"People are engaging in trolling and cyberbullying. Hiding behind devices is giving them the courage to harass other people, who can't face-to-face. This is the deterioration of moral values."

"Some companies are building strategies to use their applications for a longer time, to keep us dependent on their applications and devices so that they can display advertisements to us. And they can also use our data to manipulate our decisions for their profits. These strategies are turning humans into right targets."

"Industrialization has increased hours of work. The workers had to face inhuman conditions. Humans cannot work and concentrate continuously as machines. Fast to date, we have technological devices to check how many hours we actually work. Some companies want to be connected 24 hours a day through emails and messages. This makes people feel less human."

"Our decision-making skills are also influenced by the fact that we now ask search engines to know what is best. We depend on the internet knowledge base also at the offices to finish the work at hand. This affects cognitive abilities (thinking, reading, learning, remembering, and reason), which is an essential quality of human beings."

"Many face-to-face communications are also replaced by virtual interactions. Many people now live in virtual homes, which is the smartphone. Since the need to speak with one another is diminishing, the ability to communicate with one another, which is a basic quality of living beings, is diminishing."

"We are increasingly dependent on technological devices to guide us. For example, we keep reminders on smartphones and google questions for answers. We are outsourcing activities that require intelligence to technology. Thinking, remembering things and analyzing are essential qualities of humans. Too much technology dependence makes us less human."

"Using technology, people are maintaining and improving relationships with their friends, family and relatives. Many people are also connecting with each other to help the needy and inspire each other. So now we have better tools to build human connections."

Technology allows us to work from home. This structure is helping employers to be more understanding of employees. Many companies are now adding elements to the work culture with the help of technology to make important employees feel.

"This bill has conferred exclusive powers on the National Investigation Agency (NIA). The NIA may take any person under their custody under UAPA without taking prior permission from the state government. This is against federalism, which is guaranteed by the constitution of India."

"Labelling organisations such as terrorist organisations and people labeling as terrorists are very different. If a person is appointed as a terrorist, he will face social exclusion and will be deprived of livelihood opportunities even if he has shown otherwise. The consequences will be irreversible. For example, 67% of cases ended with absolution in 2016 alone, which means they are probably innocent."

"If anyone is booked under UAPA, the burden of proving their innocence is upon them. This new amendment allows the government to take over property. Then how will they pay the attorney's fees to prove their innocence, if they are unjustly accused?"

"This will provide more police powers to the central government. The provision of calling individuals as terrorists can be abused. For example, recently several civil activists are called Urban Naxals. If anyone opposes the government, they will be vulnerable to being framed as terrorists. Because this amendment made it easier to label anyone as a terrorist."

"There is a growing threat of lone wolf terrorism. Lonely terrorists have no association with terrorist organisations, but they commit terrorist attacks on their own. This new amendment to AUPA has the potential to curb lone wolf terrorism."

"To avoid human rights violations, a four-step examination is added. Designing individuals as terrorists didn't start in India. The United States, the European Union and China also have this provision."

"Until now, only organisations have been designated as terrorist organisations, but not as individuals. The loophole in this is the individuals of banned organisations are forming new organisations and carrying out terrorist activities. This amendment reads for illegal activities (Prevention) Act allows the government to designate individuals as terrorists, so that terrorist attacks can be avoided."
"It is necessary to act firmly against terrorism in the presence of increasing threats from terrorists. Therefore, strengthening UAPA is necessary."

"Now India does not have a well-developed infrastructure to ensure data security. On the other hand, developed countries already have an efficient infrastructure. Therefore, running towards data localization cannot be a wise step. Because without efficient infrastructure, data is subject to cyber attacks. And the risk here is serious because it's financial data. But as laws are made, it is a great challenge to develop efficient infrastructure at a faster pace."

"The storage of data in India entails higher operating costs for payment system operators. Because in other countries they have cheaper alternatives. And also for cross-border transactions, they have to store data in two places, which increases costs. These additional costs are likely to be passed on to consumers."

Data localization laws determine the creation of more data centers locally. This will create many jobs and help the country's economy immensely. It will also stimulate innovation in the sector with low-cost solutions.

"During criminal investigations, there will be a need to access payment data. If data is stored abroad, it is very difficult to obtain permission from that country for access to data. This causes delays in the resolution of crimes. If the data is stored here within our country, this problem will be avoided."

"India is a large consumer market for many foreign companies. Thus, India and other developing countries are realising the economic value of data and the importance of data localisation. With data localization, national companies and the country's economy will benefit. And we can also ensure data security."

"The data are considered to be a new form of wealth. In general, companies use data to understand the needs of consumers and also to influence their behaviour. New products can be developed by analysing data to meet consumers' needs. So the data has an economic value. In general, developed countries are exploiting this opportunity with their well-developed infrastructure."

"We are in a globalized world. Currently, the world is running on the free flow of people, goods, services and data. Data localization laws seem to be part of protectionist policies, which are a threat to the free flow of data."

"The United States is against data localization laws. Recently at the G20 summit, Donald Trump, the President of the United States spoke against data localization. Its position is natural because it increases the operating costs of US companies. Bilateral relations between India and the United States are important for both countries because we are intertwined in the export and import of computer services, professionals and goods, etc. Therefore, imposing data localization laws without threatening Indo-US relations is another challenge."
We can guarantee the privacy of the data by locating the data.
The location of the data may involve the supervision of the government of its citizens.
"Data localization is important for data sovereignty, which means that citizens' data should be owned by their respective governments and not by other countries."

The law is very clear that the RTI does not only deal with government bodies. It is also for non-governmental organizations that are substantially financed and controlled by the government. The subsidies (including tax exemptions) enjoyed by political parties are therefore substantially financed by the government.
"Political parties are independent bodies, they must not be accountable to the public. They have not been established by the constitution or an act of parliament."

"The RTI law stipulates that, wherever there is public interest, such organisations must be transparent and fall within the scope of the law. There are today a number of private organizations, partly funded or fully funded; schools, hospitals, etc. which are according to the RTI law and not only government organizations."
There are appropriate provisions in the Income Tax Act and with the Election Commission so that people can have all the information they want.

"The RTI law contains provisions in Section 8 which refer to the concept of competitive interest. Certain exemptions are provided in cases where it can be demonstrated that disclosure of information may harm the competitive advantage of the party. It is not only a problem with political parties, but also with many governments and private bodies."

"Political funding is believed to be the source of corruption. Citizens have the right to know from where political parties collect these funds, how they spend them and at the basis of their decisions. The capitalism of the chroniclers will be strongly restrained if the political parties are subjected to the RTI law."

"According to IT law, political parties do not need to reveal donations they get under INR 20,000. An informal study conducted in 2010 on 6 key political parties shows that they raised Rs 700 crore. 95% of the amount was increased with amounts less than Rs 20,000. There is a great chance that political parties will use this loophole to their advantage."
"The political parties declare certain promises in their posters. After being elected, citizens have the right to know why the promises made by political parties have not been respected."

Political parties are at the heart of the functioning of democracy. The political parties continue to form the government. Government policies are then governed by party ideology. It is therefore essential that political parties enter the framework of the RTI.

"If the political parties fall within the scope of the RTI, this will affect their proper internal functioning. Rivals can use RTI for mutual manipulation. Moreover, since political parties are not directly connected to the public, a RTI would not be valid."

"The Indians as a whole consider educational institutions as machines for work, we expect to enter unemployed and go out with employment. We do not realize that we will have to update our skills to become worthy of employment. This is why more than 80% of engineers are unemployed and the figures are even worse for non-engineers."

" Although we have established institutions at national level over the last 40 years, we have not invested to maintain their standards. Funds are needed for quality education. Even the best Indian institutions lack adequate infrastructure, laboratories, resources, etc. And even all that is available is only for the good of passing students in the exam and sitting inactive for the rest of the time."
Today no problem has a single solution and no new technology is linked to a single discipline. We need more input from more disciplines and our institutions have failed to do so.
"Indian students perform brilliantly when they go to different countries in the field of research. It means that we don't lack talent, infrastructure and a healthy environment for our sharp minds."

"We have not paid our teachers on the scale of what their counterparts earn in other countries. As a result, people are reluctant to teach as a career. We also failed to attract successful foreign faculties to our institutions."

"To achieve excellence in whatever takes time. Through graduation, students acquire a lot of knowledge in the relevant field. Thus, it is easier for employers to train these students for industrial needs."
Any skill can be learned and mastered even if we do not have a degree in this. And programming is no exception.

"Even if someone has a degree in computer science, they have to learn a lot to get into IT work, because there is a gap between industrial standards and skills that are taught in engineering colleges. Moreover, since technology is constantly evolving, even if someone has prepared for industrial standards in its graduation, he must learn new technologies continuously to remain relevant in the labour market. So, as the learning curve will also be there for IT students, non-IT background students can also learn these things and get into IT jobs."

"The number of IT jobs is growing rapidly due to the technological revolution. So there will be more jobs in the field of information technology. And if recruiters are very strict about the grade, they might lose a large pool of talents, which are a non-IT background."

"Now, we have so many online course platforms through which we can learn almost any skill from experts. We can also get certificates if we pass the tests. So, as Tim Cook said, a 4-year-old graduation looks old and traditional."

"In many engineering colleges in India, we can easily pass subjects even if they do not have much knowledge in those subjects. This is why many companies are not able to find suitable talent even if there are so many qualified graduates. Therefore, the will to become an expert in the field is more important than a degree."
"If a non-IT student has chosen to start a career in IT, the efforts they will put in place for graduation will be in vain."

"Although the new programming languages are replacing the old ones, the basic concepts are the same for almost all programming languages. So, what has a degree in encoding will have an advantage over the student from a non-IT background."

"People change careers even after working in a field for several years because our interests change.Thus, when someone can do this while having so many personal responsibilities, it is much easier for young people to learn a new skill. "

"Variable pay definitely increases employee productivity. High performance individuals feel well compensated and rewarded for their efforts, while less performing individuals also feel motivated to improve."

"In variable pay schemes, employees feel satisfied and motivated by their work. They feel an active part of the organization, the organization recognizes them as part of its growth and values their efforts."

"Variable pay helps to maintain valuable employees. This helps to maintain a good talent for long periods of time and therefore, less spending on hiring new talents. This provides stability to the organization."

" It has been seen that it is difficult to keep employees in lean times when they are on variable wage regimes. Workers receiving commissions do well when business is good, but they hurt when business is bad. In slow business times, even the best sellers may have difficulty making enough sales to earn a decent life. If the market is slow and commissioned workers can earn enough, they can look for other job opportunities. In times of lean, fixed wages can be more effective to prevent employees from leaving for other opportunities."

"Variable pay can lead to unhealthy competition between employees. They become less willing to help each other. Team cooperation can be negatively affected. In the long term, relations between colleagues can become bitter. While, in fixed pay schemes, employees are able to maintain friendly relationships in the office."

"Most sales jobs have a variable component. This could have a negative impact on employee attitudes towards customers. They can force customers irrationally only to make profits for themselves. They could overestimate the price for customers just to make more profit. While, an employee with a fixed salary would maintain healthy and positive relationships with customers, finding the right balance in their approach."

"The huge data we produce every day is analyzed and inserted into our devices through algorithms that end up giving more and more control of our lives to gadgets. We can feel that we receive all these services for free, but they come at the cost of our precious time and attention."

"With all the data and algorithms our apps and gadgets, without our conscious knowledge, are making decisions for us. Decision making is (was) one of the qualities that made humans different from others."

"After a daily shift of 10 hours from Monday to Friday most of us prefer to stay at home during the holidays. We surround ourselves with laptops, TV and mobile and use them in cycles for Netflix, sports, social media, etc. (Thinking we're relaxing) rather than going out. We prefer and are more comfortable with online chat instead of talking to people for real. Nowadays there are fewer meaningful relationships due to all the above factors. We started to prefer isolation."

"Nuclear technology is a very efficient alternative to non-renewable energy resources. However, we have chosen to move forward with more and more types of nuclear warheads. The same goes for almost every other invention. Similarly, although initially, AI promised a better life for us, because of AI, we began to lose our basic human qualities."
"We have begun to lose our basic human habits and instincts, and they are actually governed by devices and applications."

"As Yuval Noah Harari says, what we need now is morality and spirituality. Morality consists in reducing suffering in the world. And spirituality is questioning and seeking answers. Religions only provide us with answers and no scope for questions."

"Religion has served its purpose to unite people, create structures in society and develop trust and cooperation. But in the 21st century, we are thriving towards objective realities, and religion is an intersubjective reality, and now the only thing that makes it is to create differences in the world, wash your brain, develop animosity for other beliefs, and provide rituals that are just shortcuts to become a good person. (A Muslim can pray 5 times a day; a Hindu can pray every day for hours in temples; a Christian can go to church every day, but still be involved in immoral activities)."

"In the past, everything unknown had to do with religious beliefs. But now science and technology have taken over everything. We know the reasons for drought, earthquakes, wind storms, etc. are scientific phenomena and no longer the wrath of the gods."

"Because of their technological nature, new banks do not need physical bank branches, which helps them to save on general costs (the cost of managing the business). Therefore, new banks are able to offer customers lower rates and higher interest rates on control and savings accounts."

"People trust neo-banks so much because they don't have a physical presence, which makes them a risk to customers in case of problems or challenges. Customer service in person can look more reliable for customers."

Technological literacy is still very low in India. Traditional banks can meet the banking needs of less experienced technology customers or people in rural areas of the country who prefer face-to-face interaction with the manager.
"Commercial banks help to create credit, which leads to an increase in production, employment and consumer spending, which contributes to the growth of the economy."
"Since the new banks are fully digital, they operate 24 hours a day and their services can be accessible at any time. They are easy to access from anywhere through a smartphone."

"Fintech companies can open specialized neo-banks that address a specific type of customer needs. For example, LXME aims to become the first Indian Neo bank for women, which will offer product solutions that meet the specific financial needs of women and emotional preferences."
"5G in the banking sector will bring the necessary financial inclusion to the rural and remote populations of India, for which access to a physical bank is not possible."

"The low latency of 5G will allow the inclusion of education in remote areas of India, where children will have access to good quality education at home without any network delay between them and their favorite tutor. In addition, 5G will allow you to use new-age technologies such as AR and VR for more engaging learning in schools and colleges."

"5G will greatly increase the number of networks that can be connected, managing up to a trillion Internet of Things terminals, which will allow machines and humans to communicate seamlessly with each other, making the business more efficient and reducing the possibility of error."

"The government will be able to improve its governance and boost its digital India initiative, which aims to ensure that public funding services are made available electronically to citizens, making the country endowed with digital powers in the field of technology."
"The hydrogen is flammable and can cause fires or explosions. So, it's still not entirely safe."
"If the production of hydrogen fuel uses fossil fuels, this can be counterproductive. Therefore, using renewable energy to produce fuel hydrogen is important."

"The hydrogen fuel cell vehicles do not emit greenhouse gases. This helps to combat climate change. Since many countries opt for energy transition, clean hydrogen fuel vehicles together with other alternative fuel vehicles can pave the way for sustainable transport. Moreover, since these vehicles do not emit greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide, they can to a large extent reduce air pollution."
"Fossil fuel prices are constantly growing. Therefore, if other hydrogen vehicles enter the market, the price of fossil fuels can reduce."
"Hydrogen vehicles are much quieter than fossil fuel vehicles. Thus, they can also reduce noise pollution."
"If hydrogen fuel comes out into the air, it can increase global warming."

"During the pandemic period, social media helped people maintain their social life.Social media has made it possible to stay in touch with friends and loved ones at all times. We can easily know what's going on in their lives. It allowed us to communicate with more people at the same time sharing posts."

"Because of social media, we now have the opportunity to connect with many people, even if they do not live in our area. Before social media, we could interact with people from our locality or the places we go to."

"Following friends on social media and not communicating with them privately, we can only know the things they post on their accounts. Maybe we don't know much about what's really going on in their lives. That means we won't have any meaningful ties with friends. The convenience of contacting people online made us prefer to meet them outside."

"Some people now have social anxiety because they don't have enough face-to-face interactions. When we avoid talking to people for a long time, we automatically develop a fear of engaging in small talk."
Moving to social media is a big threat. It is influencing the self-esteem of many people and it is also making them avoid forming social ties.

"In the book Geni, it has been said that in the next decade we could see more young people who know only the right emojis for a situation but not the right facial expression. This can become true if we prefer virtual life over real life."

"Through close communities or micro-community based on shared social media interests together with private messaging, social media has given us the opportunity to build real connections with people with whom we can really relate."
"The NEET exam standardizes the entry criterion for medical education across the country. As a high score is required to enter government medical universities, the exam ensures meritocracy."

"But less than 20% of students pass the exam each year. From this, it is evident that the quality of medical education in other countries where Indian students are studying is not up to medical education in India. Therefore, it is very important to take steps to provide affordable and high quality medical education in India."

"Because the exam requires further studies, coaching centers are taking advantage of the situation and are loading rupees lakhs for training for the NEET exam. Therefore, because of this, students who cannot afford coaching are at a disadvantage."

"Students work hard to score well in class 12 exams, but all that hard work is not recognized. And only the NEET score is considered for entering the medical college, which is very unfair. In addition, the NEET exam is mainly based on the CBSE curriculum. Therefore, the students of the Council of State must study additional things in order to obtain a good score on the exam."

"A high score in the NEET exam is required to get admission to government medical colleges in India. It costs about 1.25 Rs Crores to study in private medical universities in India. Thus, many students are forced to go to other countries such as China, Ukraine, Russia, Philippines, etc. Pursue medical education. In those countries, medical education costs around Rs.35 lakhs. In addition, they allow students with low NEET scores, but above cut-off scores."

Some people in the moonlight to pursue their passion when the gains from their passion cannot replace the salary from their main work. Several entrepreneurs take this path and leave their jobs once they earn enough from their new businesses.
"As in a study published by the Management Journal Academy in 2021, moonlighting can provide a sense of control and motivation, which can improve employee productivity."

"Sudden dismissals by several companies, especially during the pandemic, have caused fear in many employees. And so several people took part in side concerts or a second job as a safety net in case they are fired."

Moonlighting can help improve skills. Some people want to learn new skills apart from what they are working on in their primary work. This can help them develop skills in their field. Some may get bored with monotonous work and then take the second job to learn new skills and then make their days exciting.
Companies fear the theft of sensitive information and data and the possibility to share them with their rival companies.

Some executives are concerned that employees who moonlight cannot be productive in their primary work due to fatigue and increased stress. There are also concerns about work for other companies during office hours of my primary work.

"In general, companies provide different benefits to employees such as insurance fund, health insurance, etc. So, they think it's unfair when their employees focus their energy and time on a second job, which doesn't provide any of these benefits."

"An economy without cash saves so much money for governments because printing money, and sending money to banks requires money and human resources. It will also eliminate the need to buy or rent land for ATMs. International payments will also be easier because it is not necessary to change currency."
Cashless transactions leave fingerprints on financial transactions. They can be used to track illegal activities.
COVID Pandemic has increased the number of transactions without cash. They can prevent the spread of contagious diseases.

"Cashless transactions are recorded by banks. So, the data will reveal people's critical data as to where they spend money. The government can easily access anyone's data. It can lead to mass surveillance programs. This is against the right to privacy. Money gives us anonymity."
An economy without cash will increase the number of cyber crimes.
Technical issues in the banking sector can stop access to our money. This can interfere with our daily lives.

"Refugees are forcibly displaced. They flee their country for various reasons, such as violence, human rights violations, war, persecution of minorities, etc. They often face threats to life in their countries of origin. They leave their homes and everything else in search of a safer place to live."

"Currently many countries reject refugees by claiming that they represent an economic or security threat. Only a few countries, including Lebanon, Jordan, Turkey and Liberia, accept most refugees. Some host countries are sending refugees to their countries of origin by force, saying that the situation in their countries of origin is secure. Many refugees who have been sent so have suffered brutal violence and some people have even disappeared."

All countries should share responsibility for refugees. Resettlement of refugees should take place without delay. They should be equipped with skills development courses and job opportunities to help them live a dignified life.

"A weak global response is worsening the situation of refugees. The international community should help rebuild the countries devastated by the war, from which refugees come, so that refugees can get a safe and dignified return. Refugees should not be forcibly sent to their countries of origin."
"Many developed countries are spending so much money to protect their borders, but they are not spending money to protect the lives of refugees. More funding is needed to protect refugees."

"In general, some teachers punish students, who do not have a good score in exams, but do not even try to understand if they have any learning disabilities. This causes self-esteem problems in students. Psychologists can detect these learning disabilities and can detect these problems and work with teachers to develop suitable teaching strategies for students with learning disabilities."

"Many students struggle with different issues such as anxiety, self-esteem problems, friendship training problems, etc. Guidance and support are very important to help them overcome these problems. Therefore, educational institutions should have mental health professionals to help students."

"In 2020, on average 34 students commit suicide every day due to various reasons, such as pressure from the exams, and relationship problems. Therefore, it is very important to provide them with support in educational institutions. Councillors can help them cope with pressures and can help improve their mental health. If the student suffers from mental health problems such as severe depression, counselors will take steps to make them treated by psychiatrists."

"The covid pandemic has influenced the mental health of many people. Since schools and colleges have been closed for a long time, many students have felt isolated and this has caused an even more negative impact on mental health. As schools and colleges have reopened, students need help to adapt to the new normal."

"Some students don't even understand what they're going through, maybe they don't even know how to ask for help. Having a counselor at their educational institution will greatly help them to understand their problems. Moreover, they will learn to ask for advice and help."

"When university education is free, the number of graduates will increase dramatically. At present, many people do not have access to higher education. So many students are not joining colleges because of their parents' financial status. Free education will be very useful for them."

"At the moment, the rich are becoming richer and the poor are becoming poorer. A free university education will also reduce social inequality because, as everyone can study and learn skills in college, everyone will have an equal opportunity to settle in the career of their choice."

"Some students are taking educational loans to study and then have to work hard to repay their loans. Many people are forced to hire jobs immediately after college to repay loans. But with free education, they will have freedom in career choices such as choosing a job or becoming entrepreneurs or experimenting with concerts, etc."
"In many countries there is a shortage of skilled workers. When university education is free, this problem will be solved."
"Currently, private investment in education has led to an improvement in the quality of education. Without the commercialisation of education, the quality of education cannot improve much."

"The less inconvenience to public life, less road traffic and less loss to our economy. Since all government staff can be used at once, we can also increase vigilance, and factors such as black money, booth capture, etc. may be reduced."

"To hold both elections together will also mean mixing national issues with those of the State. National issues would surpass the state which, in turn, would have less priority on the part of politicians."
When state elections are conducted together at the center regional parties can be marginalized because the same party getting majority in the center can get votes in the state as well.

"Frequent elections in the country will often bring politicians back to the public, while reducing elections would mean making them lazy for the rest of the mandate and suddenly becoming too active during the election year."

"Almost 3 lakh people were employed in the firecracker industry in these places, and 5 lakh people in packaging, transportation, distribution, and sale of these crackers. Therefore, the ban would also mean enormous unemployment in these states."

"Bursting crackers on Diwali has always been on the list of things to do in every family. A Deepavali without firecrackers will definitely be a cut in entertainment and recreation for children, as well as the elderly."

"Banning firecrackers in some places that currently have pollution at its peak as Delhi-NCR obviously cut down the poisonous emission of gas that has fatal effects on the whole balanced ecosystem. The highest level of particulate matter recorded in Delhi was 2.5 in 2016, which actually made Delhi the world's most polluted city in terms of air pollution. The Central Commission for the Control of Pollution has also declared that the level of sulphur dioxide in the air becomes tremendously high between 9 p.m. and midnight during Deepavali."

"Market-regulated crackers include chemical components such as salt, carbon and sulphur. When these ignite completely, dangerous oxides of gas are emitted which cause suffocation, reduce visibility and other health risks. Medical experts say that air is contaminated with toxic gases and remains for days after Diwali. Toxic elements reaching the lungs cannot be removed later and can cause serious health problems. This will cause long-term effects on children."

"With the ban, religious sentiments are also unleashed. In 2017, the Hindu community raised questions about the ban on Christmas trees on Christmas, or slaughter of lamb on Eid, or colors on Holi, etc., thinking they are against their common practices."

India is the second most populous country in the world. It is already difficult for the Indian government to provide food security and basic needs to all the Indian people. The addition of additional burdens will worsen the situation.

Refugee accommodation will cause some Indians to resettle. The Indian government tried to give refuge to the Rohingya by reinsecting some of them in the Jammu region. This may not be the right step and will cause anguish to the resettled Indians.

This issue should be strengthened at European level, as we never know when we will have a new crisis on our part, caused this time by climate change and environmental disasters that force people to go on diaspora and seek a safe haven."

The EU should treat economic migrants with greater vigilance. They cannot be the solution to the ageing of the European population. We need to focus more on border control to curb illegal immigration.

"The human rights-based approach should be the fundamental principle. Legal channels for entry and promotion of an integration policy based on respect for rights and equal treatment of local workers and migrants, as key tools are needed to address the social impact of migration flows."

"Migratory workers are overrepresented in the most precarious jobs, all too often underpaid, work in intolerable working conditions and live in horrible housing facilities. "Before we focus on ensuring that immigrants have good conditions in the European Union, we should first focus on ensuring that our citizens can live well-respected lives in their countries.
